News Headteacher and four other senior staff to leave failing school Colin Short has signalled he will quit as head of Reddish Vale High School after holding the position for 15 years Share Headteacher Colin Short (Photo: Handout) Share Get daily   
A headteacher has handed in his notice alongside four other senior members of staff at a failing Stockport high school. 
Colin Short has signalled he will quit as head of Reddish Vale High School after holding the position for 15 years. 
The M.E.N. can reveal the school’s deputy head, James Tipping and assistant head, Dean Thomas-Lowde, are leaving as well as the academy bursar and site manager. 
Bosses at Reddish Vale High School Academy Trust say the five separate departures are not linked to each other. Reddish Vale High School (Photo: Google) Read More Reddish Vale High School is removed from special measures 
Mr Short informed school governors of his decision on Tuesday night. He will stay on as head until the end of the end of the school term. 
The head told the M.E.N. he had resigned due to personal reasons. He said his decision was not related to the resignations of the other staff. 
In a newsletter due to be sent out to parents Thursday, the chair of Governors, Pete McCaldon, said: “This is a sad day as Mr Short has been at the school as a teacher and Headteacher for 15 years and has been unstinting in his hard work, loyalty and contribution both to the school and the local community. 
“Over the last few years he has overseen the improvement to the school including the excellent exam results last summer. I am sure you will wish to join me to thank him for his dedication to the school and to wish him the very best in his new endeavours. Reddish Vale High School Reddish Vale Technology College put into special measures after 'inadequate' Ofsted report 
“The school have also seen a number of other staff changes who have for personal reasons chosen to leave the school including Mr Tipping, Mr Thomas-Lowde, Ms Cox and Mr Ablett. “Again the school have been grateful for their devotion to the children, school and the local community over their years of service to the school; they will be sorely missed but again we wish them well in their future undertakings.” 
Reddish Vale High School, an independent academy, was the subject of a damming Ofsted report in February 2015. 
Inspectors put the school in special measures after it was judged to be criticial in all areas. 
But subsequent follow up visits had revealed signs of improvement at the school. 
It was formally taken out of special measures in February 2016 but is still rated as ‘inadequate’ by Ofsted. 
Mr Short and Mr McCaldon did not wish to issue a separate statement to the M.E.N. regarding the matter. Like us on Facebook
